programme.title: EÃ²rpa
programme.desc: New efforts are under way in Spain to address its brutal past under the dictatorship of General Franco. It's estimated the remains of thousands of people killed during the Spanish Civil War and its aftermath are buried in unmarked mass graves throughout the country. Andrew Mackinnon reports on how these graves are being exhumed in an attempt to acknowledge this dark episode of the nation's past and provide redress to the families of those who were killed.

programme.title: Ireland's Treasures Uncovered
programme.desc: The story of the iconic Irish artefacts that have helped to shape and create modern Ireland, both north and south, revealing the surprising tales behind treasures such as the Tara Broach, the Broighter Hoard, the Waterford Charter Roll and others.

programme.title: Arctic with Bruce Parry
programme.desc: Bruce travels to Alaska, America's last great wilderness, where modern-day pioneers are harvesting the vast natural wealth of the seas. Bruce learns the ropes onboard a salmon-fishing boat, and dives to the bottom of the Bering Sea to look for gold. In the far north Bruce witnesses the annual whale hunt of the Inupiak people whose ancient tradition is now at odds with the modern world.

programme.title: Pain and Glory
programme.desc: A film director reflects on the choices he's made in life as the past and present come crashing down around him.

programme.title: The Human Voice
programme.desc: A woman watches time passing next to the suitcases of her ex-lover (who is supposed to come pick them up, but never arrives) and a restless dog who doesn't understand that his master has abandoned him. Two living beings facing abandonment.

programme.title: Wogan: The Best Of
programme.desc: The line-up includes early appearances from Steve Coogan and Harry Enfield, classic encounters with Pete and Dud, Les Dawson and Ernie Wise, and a sparkling turn from American funnyman Billy Crystal.

programme.title: Yes, Prime Minister
programme.desc: Jim must recommend the appointment of bishops to the Queen but is not keen on the two offered by the Church, and Humphrey has his own reasons for wanting a third.

programme.title: Keeping Up Appearances
programme.desc: Hyacinth finds herself with an ideal opportunity to impress Emmet with her singing when she discovers that he is involved in a concert at the church hall. However, Richard has other things on his mind, dreading the thought of early retirement and having to spend more time with his wife.

programme.title: Cornwall's Red River
programme.desc: Poet John Wedgwood Clarke explores the Red River in Cornwall, a watercourse barely more than a stream that has been heavily polluted by centuries of tin mining. Now, this powerful symbol of Cornish identity, home to some very rare, beautiful and resilient species, is slowly showing signs of coming back to life. Extracts from John's poem, `Red River at the A30 Culvert', reveal his mixed thoughts about the river's toxic legacy.

programme.title: The Birth of British Music
programme.desc: Conductor Charles Hazlewood discovers how the music of Mendelssohn embodies the sound of the Victorian age. His overture to `A Midsummer Night's Dream' captured the Victorians' fondness for fairy stories, and he pioneered the use of a new conductor's tool - the baton. Charles' journey includes a trip to Birmingham Town Hall where a massed choir performs extracts from Mendelssohn's iconic work `Elijah'.

programme.title: Steps of Freedom: The Story of Irish Dance
programme.desc: Across the world, Irish dance has captivated people's imaginations. This exploration of the art form tells the story of how Irish dance evolved from a peasant dance to become a global phenomenon.

programme.title: The White Handkerchief
programme.desc: 30th January 2022 marked the fiftieth anniversary of Bloody Sunday. As the people of Derry city came together to commemorate the event, a new piece of musical theatre was staged in the Guildhall, the intended but never-reached destination for the fateful 1972 civil rights march. Commissioned by the city's Playhouse Theatre, `The White Handkerchief' seeks to create a dramatic elegy to the 13 killed, alongside those others injured, and to catalyse a creative legacy from those devastating events.

programme.title: Seamus Heaney: The Music of What Matters
programme.desc: Born into a farming family in rural Northern Ireland, Seamus Heaney became the finest poet of his generation and winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1995, but his career coincided with one of the bloodiest political upheavals of the twentieth century, the Troubles in Northern Ireland. Six years after Heaney's death in 2013, his wife Marie and his children talk about their family life and read some of the poems he wrote for them.

programme.title: Songs of Ireland
programme.desc: Featuring some of the finest Irish singers and musicians, recorded in the Glasgow Royal Concert Hall at Celtic Connections 2012. Eleanor McEvoy, Finbar Furey, Cara Dillon, Luka Bloom, Brian Kennedy and many others sing the songs that Ireland is famous for. Love songs, songs of emigration, songs of loss, contemporary and traditional are all beautifully accompanied by the house band, top Irish American group Solas.

programme.title: The Beauty of Diagrams
programme.desc: Mathematician Marcus du Sautoy explores the stories behind some of the most familiar scientific diagrams. He looks at the Vitruvian Man, Leonardo da Vinci's diagram of the perfect human body, which has many layers from anatomy to architecture, and defines our species like no other drawing. Drawn in the 1480s in Milan, it synthesises Leonardo's passions for anatomy, for the mechanics of the human body and geometry.

programme.title: The Beauty of Diagrams
programme.desc: When Nicolaus Copernicus developed his theory of a sun-centred universe 500 years ago, he was flying in the face of both science and religion. Mankind believed that the earth was at the centre of the cosmos, and to disagree was to risk derision and accusations of heresy. A young German scientist gave Copernicus the courage to publish his book and its extraordinary diagram of a heliocentric universe.

programme.title: The Birth of British Music
programme.desc: Conductor Charles Hazlewood discovers how the music of Mendelssohn embodies the sound of the Victorian age. His overture to `A Midsummer Night's Dream' captured the Victorians' fondness for fairy stories, and he pioneered the use of a new conductor's tool - the baton. Charles' journey includes a trip to Birmingham Town Hall where a massed choir performs extracts from Mendelssohn's iconic work `Elijah'.

programme.title: Seamus Heaney: The Music of What Matters
programme.desc: Born into a farming family in rural Northern Ireland, Seamus Heaney became the finest poet of his generation and winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1995, but his career coincided with one of the bloodiest political upheavals of the twentieth century, the Troubles in Northern Ireland. Six years after Heaney's death in 2013, his wife Marie and his children talk about their family life and read some of the poems he wrote for them.

programme.title: Fred Dibnah's World of Steam, Steel and Stone
programme.desc: Fred shares his respect for the great engineers of the Victorian age and explores how their belief in the values of hard work and enterprise drove them on.

programme.title: Canal Boat Diaries
programme.desc: Narrowboater Robbie Cumming begins his 170-mile journey across the north of England and soon runs into difficulty when he encounters a propeller problem in Wigan and runs aground in Blackburn. Nevertheless, he pushes on to navigate a true wonder of the waterways, the Burnley Embankment.

programme.title: Britain's Lost Masterpieces
programme.desc: Bendor Grosvenor and Emma Dabiri visit Brighton Museum to investigate who painted two neglected pictures of religious subjects. Bendor believes a grubby image of Mary Magdalene repenting her sins may be by a forgotten master of Francesco Trevisani.

programme.title: The Golden Age of Canals
programme.desc: Most people thought that when the working traffic on canals faded away after the war, it would be the end of their story. However, a few diehard enthusiasts and boat owners campaigned, lobbied and dug to keep the network of narrow canals open. Home movies made by some of these enthusiasts tell the story of how they saved the inland waterways for the nation and created a second golden age of the canals.

programme.title: Ian Hislop's Stiff Upper Lip: An Emotional History of Britain
programme.desc: Ian Hislop asks when and why we British have bottled up or let out our feelings and how this has affected our history. This is a narrative history of emotion and identity over the last 300 years. Far from being part of our cultural DNA, emotional restraint was a relatively recent national trait. Foreigners in Tudor England couldn't believe how touchy-feely we could be.

programme.title: Imagine...
programme.desc: Alan Yentob presents a profile of the provocative French-born American artist Louise Bourgeois, who was still producing cutting-edge work at the age of 95. Memories of a disturbed childhood have produced fantastic and disturbing sculptures of giant spiders and poured-plastic body parts. As a girl, she restored old tapestries, worked with Leger, and knew surrealists like Breton and Duchamp.

programme.title: James May's Cars of the People
programme.desc: James travels to Germany, Italy and Russia to reveal the story of how dictators kick-started their plans to mobilise the masses. It's a tale of design brilliance, abject failure, war, fraud and double-dealing.

programme.title: Canal Boat Diaries
programme.desc: Narrowboater Robbie Cumming begins his 170-mile journey across the north of England and soon runs into difficulty when he encounters a propeller problem in Wigan and runs aground in Blackburn. Nevertheless, he pushes on to navigate a true wonder of the waterways, the Burnley Embankment.

programme.title: Britain's Most Fragile Treasure
programme.desc: Historian Dr Janina Ramirez unlocks the secrets of a centuries-old masterpiece in glass, the East Window at York Minster - the largest medieval stained-glass window in the country and the creative vision of a master craftsman called John Thornton. Within its 311 panels is the entire history of the world.

programme.title: The Treasure Hunters
programme.desc: Ellie ventures down one of the deepest gold mines in the world and Dallas free-dives for lustrous pearls in the waters around North-West Australia.

programme.title: The Treasure Hunters

programme.desc: A media crackdown in Russia, including a new law against `fake news', has led many independent news outlets to shut down. Some major western media have pulled out of the country completely. But the BBC is not only staying, it is actually increasing its services aimed at Russians.

programme.desc: Since Russia invaded Ukraine more than 2 million people have fled the country. Hundreds of thousands of them have passed through Lviv train station, heading for Platform 5. That's where trains take women and children to safety beyond Ukraine's borders, and where many families have to part. Fergal Keane tells the stories of the people on the platform hoping to escape, the staff who bravely keep the station running and those who are left behind.

programme.title: Ukrainecast and the Global News Podcast
programme.desc: Gabriel Gatehouse and Vitaliy Shevchenko and Jackie Leonard come together for this special programme answering questions about the historical context of the war in Ukraine, the nuclear threat from Russia, and the information war happening online. And James Landale, comes on to tell us about what impact the Western sanctions are having on Russia.

programme.title: HARDtalk
programme.desc: With the world focused on Russia's invasion of Ukraine it's easy to overlook one other key element of Vladimir Putin's Greater Russia strategy. Moscow's ever tighter grip on Ukraine's northern neighbour Belarus, now used as a launchpad for the Ukraine assault. Belarus's authoritarian President Lukashenko seems to be in Putin's pocket, whether he likes it or not. Stephen Sackur speaks to the exiled leader of the anti-Lukashenko movement Svetlana Tikhanovskaya.

programme.title: We Are England
programme.desc: Neighbours on a Leeds housing estate fight to keep their community together when faced with eviction from their privately rented homes, which have stood since the 1950s. The residents' battle highlights the strength of community in working-class neighbourhoods, and speaks to issues of gentrification seen across the country. This film follows several residents on the estate in the weeks leading up to their eviction, as they desperately fight for more time and for their community to stay together.

programme.title: The Witches of Eastwick
programme.desc: Three frustrated female divorcees living in a quiet town wish for the perfect man to enter their lives. When a mysterious, rich and charming stranger buys a mansion in the community, it looks like their prayers have been answered - but the man they appear to have summoned seems more than a little devilish. Based on John Updike's novel.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: The BBC's Breakfast programme features the latest news, sport, business, weather and other items on a daily basis.

programme.title: Saturday Kitchen Live
programme.desc: Matt Tebbutt and chefs Ben Tish and Joe Wicks are joined by special guest Rose Matafeo. There are great moments from the BBC food archive, including clips from Rick Stein, Keith Floyd, Nigella Lawson and Mary Berry, and drinks expert Helen McGinn joins via video link to pick the wines to go with the studio dishes.

programme.title: Marcus Wareing's Tales from a Kitchen Garden
programme.desc: Marcus Wareing embraces a slower pace of life down at his Sussex smallholding. Setting out to expand the range of produce and bring in new livestock, his first additions are some new pigs, but he needs to choose animals that will provide him with the best possible meat. He heads to North Yorkshire to meet the rare Mangalitza pigs, who are famed for their deep flavour and fun personalities.

programme.title: Football Focus
programme.desc: Alex Scott and her guests reflect on the latest football headlines and look ahead to the weekend's action, which includes a clash between Manchester United and Tottenham Hotspur. In the reverse fixture earlier in the season, a 3-0 win by the Red Devils helped spell the end for Spurs boss Nuno Espirito Santo, who was sacked in the aftermath of the match.

programme.title: BBC Weekend News
programme.desc: National and international news, followed by weather.

programme.title: BBC Weather
programme.desc: The latest weather forecast.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: The teams are let loose in the antiques fair taking place amongst the bloom and blossom of Carmarthenshire. Keeping them in check are experts Nick Hall and Gary Pe, while Charlie finds out more about the age-old use of medicinal plants.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Ginny Buckley meets a couple who are looking to return to their Welsh homeland after 20 years of living in Oxford. The pair have a budget of Â£450,000 to find the right home in Carmarthenshire with enough land to accommodate visiting friends and their pooches. Elsewhere, Ginny samples a regional delicacy at Britain's only manufacturer of pickled cockles.

programme.title: Money for Nothing
programme.desc: Sarah Moore is at Wallyford Recycling Centre in East Lothian, hoping to unearth some quality discards before they hit the rubbish heap. With the help of bag maker Neil Wragg and screen-print artist Daniel Heath, Sarah hopes to breathe new life into a leaking tent, a scandi style coffee table and a miniature greenhouse. But will she harvest any profits by selling them on?

programme.title: Garden Rescue
programme.desc: In Bristol, Vanessa and her two boys have an overgrown concrete jungle for a back garden. They want to create a Moroccan holiday-inspired eco-friendly wildlife haven full of bugs, bees and birds but they have no idea where to start.

programme.title: Final Score
programme.desc: Jason Mohammad presents the fast-paced football results service, with goal flashes, reports and interviews from across the country, as well as analysis from the studio guests.

programme.title: Superman & Lois
programme.desc: Superman pays a visit to Morgan Edge; Lois and Chrissy work together on a story; Jonathan finds a welcome distraction during a very stressful school day.

programme.title: BBC Weekend News
programme.desc: National and international news, followed by weather.

programme.title: BBC London
programme.desc: News, sport and weather from London.

programme.title: BBC Weather
programme.desc: The latest weather forecast.

programme.title: Celebrity Mastermind
programme.desc: Philippa Dunne, Phil Wang, Keith Brymer Jones and Dani Harmer are put to the test by Clive Myrie. Specialist subjects include `The Shining', the wines of New Zealand, Dame Lucie Rie, and `RuPaul's Drag Race UK'.

programme.title: The Wall
programme.desc: Danny Dyer hosts as comedians Shaparak Khorsandi and Ellie Taylor tackle the biggest opponent on TV. The question is whether they will be laughing all the way to the bank, or if the evil Superdrop will dampen the atmosphere.

programme.title: Pointless Celebrities
programme.desc: A special soaps edition of the general knowledge quiz. Contestants Adjoa Andoh, John Altman, Nick Cochrane, Paul Usher, Tricia Penrose, Denise Black, Jennifer Ellison and Ann Marie Davies try to come up with the answers no-one else could think of.

programme.title: Casualty
programme.desc: Iain risks everything to help a patient in a desperate situation, and Paul encourages Robyn to be bold.

programme.title: Killing Eve
programme.desc: Eve locates Helene, who may be useful in her revenge mission against the Twelve. Villanelle's quest for change goes awry. Carolyn is pushed aside by MI6, so is forced to seek cooperation elsewhere as she needs to find out who ordered Kenny's hit.

programme.title: BBC Weekend News
programme.desc: National and international news, followed by weather.

programme.title: BBC Weather

programme.title: Match of the Day
programme.desc: Gary Lineker introduces highlights, reaction and analysis from the day's six Premier League games, including the battle between top-four contenders Manchester United and Tottenham. It is a fixture that rarely disappoints.

programme.title: The Limehouse Golem
programme.desc: Victorian London is gripped with fear as a serial killer is on the loose, leaving cryptic messages written in the blood of his victims. With few leads and increasing public pressure, Scotland Yard assigns the case to Inspector Kildare, a seasoned detective who has a sneaking suspicion that he's being set up to fail. Faced with a long list of suspects, Kildare must rely on help from a witness to stop the murders and bring the maniac to justice.

That's where trains take women and children to safety beyond Ukraine's borders, and where many families have to part. Fergal Keane tells the stories of the people on the platform hoping to escape, the staff who bravely keep the station running and those who are left behind.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: Twenty-four hours a day, the latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Ukraine: Reporting From the Frontlines
programme.desc: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has caused the fastest-growing refugee crisis in Europe since World War II, as Ukrainians across the country flee to the West, desperately trying to save themselves from Russian bombardment. Yalda Hakim and the BBC's teams on the frontlines of this conflict, both inside Ukraine and the countries on its borders, report on the events of another seismic week.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: Twenty-four hours a day, the latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: The Media Show
programme.desc: A media crackdown in Russia, including a new law against `fake news', has led many independent news outlets to shut down. Some major western media have pulled out of the country completely. But the BBC is not only staying, it is actually increasing its services aimed at Russians.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: The BBC's Breakfast programme features the latest news, sport, business, weather and other items on a daily basis.

programme.title: Match of the Day
programme.desc: Gary Lineker introduces highlights, reaction and analysis from the day's six Premier League games, including the battle between top-four contenders Manchester United and Tottenham. It is a fixture that rarely disappoints.

programme.title: Sunday Morning
programme.desc: Interviews with leading politicians and topical debate.

programme.title: Sunday Politics Northern Ireland

Special guests Nish Kumar and Anita Rani share their favourite Holi traditions, and chefs Vivek Singh and Saransh Goila offer ideas about what to cook during the festival. With treats from the BBC food archive from Madhur Jaffrey and Sanjeev Bhaskar.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: An end of terrace house in Hounslow in Middlesex, a flat in Stone in Staffordshire and six and a half acres of land in Bargoed in Wales are all sold under the hammer. Not everything goes according to plan for the new owners.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: In Hungerford, Anita Manning takes up the reins with experts Philip Serrell and Richard Madley. The reds and blues race around the high street hoping to bag themselves a bargain and make a profit at auction.

programme.desc: National and international news, followed by weather.

programme.title: Weather for the Week Ahead

programme.title: Songs of Praise
programme.desc: The Rev Kate Bottley explores the ancient rhythm of prayer and work practised by the Roman Catholic monks of Mount St Bernard's Abbey in Leicestershire. She speaks to the brothers about their calling and the purpose of the monastic community, and also samples the renowned Trappist beer brewed in the monastery.

programme.title: Kung Fu Panda 3
programme.desc: After reuniting with his long-lost father, Po must train a village of clumsy pandas to help him defeat a supernatural warrior who becomes stronger with each battle.

programme.title: Dodger
programme.desc: Twelve-year-old orphan Jack Dawkins escapes a mill owner's clutches. With the help of new friend Charley, they make it to London, where they first meet Fagin's infamous gang.

programme.title: Frozen Planet
programme.desc: Revealing the extraordinary riches and wonders of the polar regions that have kept people visiting them for thousands of years. Today, their survival relies on a combination of ancient wisdom and cutting-edge science. Most Arctic people live in Siberia, either in cities like Norilsk - the coldest city on earth - or out on the tundra, where tribes like the Dogan survive by herding reindeer.

programme.desc: National and international news, followed by weather.

programme.title: Countryfile
programme.desc: In the wake of recent storms that have rampaged across the UK, Charlotte Smith and Tom Heap are on the River Severn to find out how living with the constant threat of floods is affecting rural communities, and how climate change could make things worse. Adam Henson checks in with farmers to see how flooding impacts their livelihoods, and Matt Baker is at Steart Marsh by the Severn estuary to discover how surrendering to the waters can help wildlife.

programme.title: Extraordinary Portraits
programme.desc: Dale Grimshaw, famed for creating street murals with a fine-art approach, builds a special bond with Patrick, a personal trainer from south London. Patrick was photographed carrying an injured English Defence League member to safety during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in 2020, and was propelled into the media spotlight both here and around the world. This powerful image and act of kindness was hailed as a symbol of unity and humanity.

programme.title: The British Academy Film Awards
programme.desc: The Royal Albert Hall in London rolls out the red carpet to celebrate the achievements of those in front of and behind the camera during the past year in cinema. Presented by actress and comedian Rebel Wilson, the 75th British Academy Film Awards gathers together this year's nominees to find out who will be walking away with a coveted Bafta award. Nominated films include `No Time to Die', `Dune', `Belfast', `Licorice Pizza', `King Richard', `Don't Look Up' and `The Power of the Dog'.

programme.title: Peaky Blinders

programme.desc: Neighbours on a Leeds housing estate fight to keep their community together when faced with eviction from their privately rented homes, which have stood since the 1950s. programme.desc: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has caused the fastest-growing refugee crisis in Europe since World War II, as Ukrainians across the country flee to the West, desperately trying to save themselves from Russian bombardment. Yalda Hakim and the BBC's teams on the frontlines of this conflict, both inside Ukraine and the countries on its borders, report on the events of another seismic week.

programme.desc: A media crackdown in Russia, including a new law against `fake news', has led many independent news outlets to shut down. Some major western media have pulled out of the country completely. But the BBC is not only staying, it is actually increasing its services aimed at Russians.

programme.title: Songs of Praise
programme.desc: The Rev Kate Bottley explores the ancient rhythm of prayer and work practised by the Roman Catholic monks of Mount St Bernard's Abbey in Leicestershire. She speaks to the brothers about their calling and the purpose of the monastic community, and also samples the renowned Trappist beer brewed in the monastery.

programme.title: Frozen Planet
programme.desc: Revealing the extraordinary riches and wonders of the polar regions that have kept people visiting them for thousands of years. Today, their survival relies on a combination of ancient wisdom and cutting-edge science. Most Arctic people live in Siberia, either in cities like Norilsk - the coldest city on earth - or out on the tundra, where tribes like the Dogan survive by herding reindeer.

programme.desc: In the wake of recent storms that have rampaged across the UK, Charlotte Smith and Tom Heap are on the River Severn to find out how living with the constant threat of floods is affecting rural communities, and how climate change could make things worse. Adam Henson checks in with farmers to see how flooding impacts their livelihoods, and Matt Baker is at Steart Marsh by the Severn estuary to discover how surrendering to the waters can help wildlife.

programme.title: Extraordinary Portraits

Patrick was photographed carrying an injured English Defence League member to safety during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in 2020, and was propelled into the media spotlight both here and around the world. This powerful image and act of kindness was hailed as a symbol of unity and humanity.

programme.title: The British Academy Film Awards

Nominated films include `No Time to Die', `Dune', `Belfast', `Licorice Pizza', `King Richard', `Don't Look Up' and `The Power of the Dog'.

programme.desc: Gary Lineker introduces highlights, reaction and analysis from the day's six Premier League games, including the battle between top-four contenders Manchester United and Tottenham. It is a fixture that rarely disappoints.

programme.title: Sunday Morning
programme.desc: Interviews with leading politicians and topical debate.

programme.title: Politics Wales
programme.desc: All the latest political news from Wales and beyond.

programme.title: Saturday Kitchen Live
programme.desc: Matt Tebbutt hosts a special edition in celebration of Holi. Special guests Nish Kumar and Anita Rani share their favourite Holi traditions, and chefs Vivek Singh and Saransh Goila offer ideas about what to cook during the festival. With treats from the BBC food archive from Madhur Jaffrey and Sanjeev Bhaskar.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: An end of terrace house in Hounslow in Middlesex, a flat in Stone in Staffordshire and six and a half acres of land in Bargoed in Wales are all sold under the hammer. Not everything goes according to plan for the new owners.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: In Hungerford, Anita Manning takes up the reins with experts Philip Serrell and Richard Madley. The reds and blues race around the high street hoping to bag themselves a bargain and make a profit at auction.

programme.title: BBC Weekend News
programme.desc: National and international news, followed by weather.

programme.title: Weather for the Week Ahead
programme.desc: Detailed weather forecast.

programme.title: Songs of Praise
programme.desc: The Rev Kate Bottley explores the ancient rhythm of prayer and work practised by the Roman Catholic monks of Mount St Bernard's Abbey in Leicestershire. She speaks to the brothers about their calling and the purpose of the monastic community, and also samples the renowned Trappist beer brewed in the monastery.

programme.title: Kung Fu Panda 3
programme.desc: After reuniting with his long-lost father, Po must train a village of clumsy pandas to help him defeat a supernatural warrior who becomes stronger with each battle.

programme.title: Dodger
programme.desc: Twelve-year-old orphan Jack Dawkins escapes a mill owner's clutches. With the help of new friend Charley, they make it to London, where they first meet Fagin's infamous gang.

programme.title: Frozen Planet
programme.desc: Revealing the extraordinary riches and wonders of the polar regions that have kept people visiting them for thousands of years. Today, their survival relies on a combination of ancient wisdom and cutting-edge science. Most Arctic people live in Siberia, either in cities like Norilsk - the coldest city on earth - or out on the tundra, where tribes like the Dogan survive by herding reindeer.

programme.title: Countryfile
programme.desc: In the wake of recent storms that have rampaged across the UK, Charlotte Smith and Tom Heap are on the River Severn to find out how living with the constant threat of floods is affecting rural communities, and how climate change could make things worse. Adam Henson checks in with farmers to see how flooding impacts their livelihoods, and Matt Baker is at Steart Marsh by the Severn estuary to discover how surrendering to the waters can help wildlife.

programme.title: Extraordinary Portraits
programme.desc: Dale Grimshaw, famed for creating street murals with a fine-art approach, builds a special bond with Patrick, a personal trainer from south London. Patrick was photographed carrying an injured English Defence League member to safety during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in 2020, and was propelled into the media spotlight both here and around the world. This powerful image and act of kindness was hailed as a symbol of unity and humanity.

programme.title: The British Academy Film Awards
programme.desc: The Royal Albert Hall in London rolls out the red carpet to celebrate the achievements of those in front of and behind the camera during the past year in cinema. Presented by actress and comedian Rebel Wilson, the 75th British Academy Film Awards gathers together this year's nominees to find out who will be walking away with a coveted Bafta award. Nominated films include `No Time to Die', `Dune', `Belfast', `Licorice Pizza', `King Richard', `Don't Look Up' and `The Power of the Dog'.

programme.title: Peaky Blinders
programme.desc: Faced with devastating news, Tommy goes on a quest to discover who it was that placed a curse on his family. In Birmingham, Ada takes charge, and Arthur takes on some new recruits.

programme.desc: A media crackdown in Russia, including a new law against `fake news', has led many independent news outlets to shut down. Some major western media have pulled out of the country completely. But the BBC is not only staying, it is actually increasing its services aimed at Russians.

programme.title: We Are England
programme.desc: Neighbours on a Leeds housing estate fight to keep their community together when faced with eviction from their privately rented homes, which have stood since the 1950s. The residents' battle highlights the strength of community in working-class neighbourhoods, and speaks to issues of gentrification seen across the country. This film follows several residents on the estate in the weeks leading up to their eviction, as they desperately fight for more time and for their community to stay together.

programme.title: The Mystery of Anthrax Island
programme.desc: Anthrax is a rare disease caused by naturally occurring bacteria which can form spores that are fatal to humans and animals. During the Second World War, government scientists from Porton Down attempted to weaponise anthrax, creating a deadly strain that they then tested on Gruinard Island, an uninhabited remote site off the coast of Scotland. This proved disastrous for Gruinard and, from 1942 onwards, people were forbidden from setting foot on the island.

programme.desc: Iain begins a new 131-mile ramble as he heads north to tackle the Speyside Way. The beginning of the Speyside Way is not far from the home of Iain's 99-year-old aunt Mary.

programme.desc: Paul explores some lochs close to Scotland's densely populated central belt. Starting on the banks of the Lake of Menteith, Paul wanders through an enchanted landscape, visiting Loch Ard, Loch Arklet, Loch Katrine and Loch Achray.

programme.desc: Saffron Events owner Hassan and his team of wedding planners help former employee Shabnum plan a series of spectacular events for her brother Naiem. Shabnum soon discovers that planning a wedding for family brings a whole lot of extra stress.

programme.desc: Wildlife rescue officer Bob has interesting cases to deal with on his round including a bat caught in a light fitting, a stranded collared dove chick and a lost racing pigeon.

programme.title: This Farming Life
programme.desc: The first snowfall of winter arrives. In Orkney, Sean works with his dad Michael and Uncle Martin in stormy weather to bring their cows in for shelter. Later, Sean reveals he's one step closer to the dream of owning his own farm.

programme.title: The Nine
programme.desc: All the national, UK-wide and international news that matters to you plus weather, entertainment news and sport - live with Laura Miller and John Beattie.

programme.title: Return to Real Kashmir FC
programme.desc: Follow-up programme to the 2019 Bafta Scotland-winning Real Kashmir FC which sees former Aberdeen and Rangers star Davie Robertson return to India to manage Real Kashmir FC. \Davie hoped many of the problems of last year would be solved, but on the very same day that he arrives the team are thrown into a political firestorm as Kashmir's devolved status is abolished, with the state being brought under the direct control of India.

programme.title: The Fort
programme.desc: Dubbed Britain's worst football team, Fort William FC sits at the foot of Ben Nevis in the Scottish Highlands. Filmed during the new management's first season in charge of the club, the documentary follows the struggles of the Highland League side on and off the pitch and the lives of the locals for whom the club means so much. For a long time FWFC have been serial losers. They have finished bottom of the Highland League for 14 of the past seasons.

programme.title: Panorama
programme.desc: Current affairs programme, featuring interviews and investigative reports on all aspects of life in Britain.

programme.title: Great Coastal Railway Journeys
programme.desc: From Britain's northernmost station at Thurso in Caithness, Michael Portillo heads for the ferry port of Scrabster to cross the Pentland Firth to the Orkney Islands. Passing the Old Man of Hoy, Michael takes in stunning views of the Orkney archipelago and the rugged coastlines of its 70 islands. Michael reaches land at Stromness on the largest of the islands, Mainland, and heads for Kirkwall, its most historic town.

programme.title: This Is BBC TWO
programme.desc: A preview of upcoming programmes from BBC Two.

programme.title: The Dengineers
programme.desc: Joe and Meryl take a look back at some of the amazing dens from the series and catch up with our Dengineers to see how the dens have changed their lives. Joe revisits the Queen Victoria, Australia, Sewing and Army Coding Dens.

programme.title: Blue Peter
programme.desc: Junior `Bake Off' winner Kezia joins us in the studio to make some Red Nose Day cupcakes and set our presenters a baking challenge! Plus, Richie and Mwaksy go head-to-head in an ice-hockey match.

programme.title: Deadly 60
programme.desc: Steve and the crew visit the southern states of the USA in search of more predators to add to his "Deadly list". He dives into the crystal clear waters of the Silver Springs River to swim with a wild alligator and adds his first plant to the list, a carnivorous venus flytrap. He also feels the sting of the formidable Fire Ant and joins a team of scientists, tracking and tagging wild bobcats.

programme.title: Malory Towers
programme.desc: The girls arrange a special surprise for Ellen, but it soon backfires. Meanwhile, Darrell uncovers information that threatens the future of Malory Towers.

programme.title: Malory Towers
programme.desc: Gwen auditions for the lead role in the upcoming school play, but it doesn't go as well as she hoped. Meanwhile, Darrell and Sally try to work on a plan to save the school.

programme.title: Forces of Nature with Brian Cox
programme.desc: Brian shows how Earth's basic ingredients, like the pure sulphur mined in the heart of a deadly volcano in Indonesia, have become the building blocks of life. Hidden deep in a cave in the Dominican Republic lies a magical world created by the same property of water that makes it essential to life.

programme.title: Earth's Greatest Spectacles
programme.desc: The Okavango Delta is one of the world's largest inland deltas - and supports a variety of life as rich as any you'll see in Africa. Yet this lush wetland of islands and lagoons lies in the middle of the vast, featureless Kalahari Desert. This is the story of how it happens. Following groups of wildlife, including hippos, baboons, catfish, kingfishers, leopards, warthogs and elephants, the film reveals how the yearly flood transforms the landscape and impacts their lives.

programme.title: Down the Mighty River with Steve Backshall
programme.desc: Steve starts his journey at Lake Habema, the body of water where the Baliem River begins its life. Embarking on a perilous expedition, Steve encounters some of the most extreme white water rapids seen anywhere on the planet.

programme.title: Great British Menu
programme.desc: Four newcomers compete: Luke French, who runs Nordic/Japanese influenced restaurant JÃ¶ro, Liz Cottam, whose restaurant Home opened in 2017, Mark Aisthorpe, chef patron of the Bull's Head in Holymoorside, and Bobby Geetha, chef patron of Fleur CafÃ©.

programme.title: Great British Menu
programme.desc: The three chefs are halfway through their heat, and the pressure is mounting. Once again, they each serve their unique interpretations of the brief celebrating 100 years of British broadcasting. For mains, chefs take inspiration from the first royal Christmas message on the radio, `Strictly Come Dancing', and a third has created an ode to Ant and Dec's `Saturday Night Takeaway'. For dessert, there are celebrations of `Darling Buds of May', `Downton Abbey' and the London 2012 Olympics.

programme.title: Oz the Great and Powerful
programme.desc: A brash showman who performs tricks rather than real magic is abruptly transported to fantastical Oz, where witch Theodora believes him to be the great wizard a prophecy says will save the land, though her sister Evanora is less convinced.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: Revisiting locations from the series, including the Ulster Folk and Transport Museum, Croombe in south Worcestershire and Crowcombe Court in Somerset. There are some items to take to auction, and Paul Martin discovers a hidden pocket of Cornwall.

programme.title: Garden Rescue
programme.desc: Reverend Karen and her husband Colin want a private Italian-themed garden for their Romsey house. Karen is the head of spiritual care at the local hospital, an emotionally draining job, so she needs the garden to be a calm space where she can recharge after work. They have a Â£6,000 budget, but it is going to be stretched, as their weed-filled garden lacks a patio, is overlooked by neighbours and is a challenging shape. But if anyone can fix those problems, it's Charlie and the Rich brothers.

programme.title: Gardeners' World
programme.desc: Monty and team share the best practical gardening advice, meet passionate plants-people up and down the country, and provide inspiration with visits to some of the UK's most remarkable gardens.

programme.title: Beautiful Interiors Northern Ireland
programme.desc: A trip to Portugal transforms a holiday home into a light-filled luxurious space filled with bespoke pieces. Design concepts include a chandelier made of Murano glass for the hallway, a vanity unit with teardrop-shaped mirrors for the bathroom, and a media wall with a eucalyptus wood finish for the living room. There's also a new sun lounge for a house in county Down with custom-made sofas and a footstool.

programme.title: The Radio 2 Piano Room
programme.desc: Much-loved music stars perform alongside the BBC Concert Orchestra at the BBC's Maida Vale Studios.

programme.title: Top of the Pops
programme.desc: As the 1990s start to get going, 1991 is the year in which indie kids, ravers, alternative comedians and even a certain grunge band from Seattle hit the charts against the background of recession and a war in the Middle East.

programme.title: Top of the Pops
programme.desc: A look in the BBC vaults to showcase and celebrate the biggest and best performances of 1991, including Right Said Fred, Seal, Mariah Carey, Nirvana, Bryan Adams and The KLF.

programme.title: R.E.M. at the BBC
programme.desc: In September 2011 R.E.M., the rock band from Athens, Georgia, decided to call it a day after 31 years. This collection from the BBC archives includes performances of `Pretty Persuasion' from the Old Grey Whistle Test in 1984, `Orange Crush' on Top of the Pops in 1989 and special acoustic versions of `Losing My Religion' and `Half a World Away' on The Late Show in 1991.

programme.title: When Nirvana Came to Britain
programme.desc: Thirty years on since the release of their seminal album "Nevermind", this documentary examines the special relationship between Nirvana and the UK, including the role Britain played in paving the way for their global success.

programme.title: Madonna: Truth or Dare
programme.desc: Madonna's candid, revealing documentary which was filmed to accompany her controversial "Blond Ambition' tour in 1990. Famous faces, including her then-boyfriend Warren Beatty, Antonio Banderas, Pedro Almodovar and Sandra Bernhard make fleeting appearances, but it's her surrogate family - the tour's performers - who get the lion"s share of the limelight.

programme.title: This Is BBC TWO
programme.desc: A preview of upcoming programmes from BBC Two.

programme.title: Sunday Morning Stories
programme.desc: Kate Bottley explores the value of kindness, discovering the remarkable generosity of individuals who offer their compassion and the purest form of love to help others, regardless of their spiritual beliefs.

programme.title: A Tale of Five Temples: The Story of Hinduism in Britain
programme.desc: Exploring the history of five Hindu temples across Britain, tracing their stories and the spread of Hinduism in the UK. Featuring the elaborate rituals and the moving stories of Hindu worshippers, the film gives an insight into the sheer variety of Hindu beliefs across Britain. A story of protest and love, beauty and hope.

programme.title: Christine's Garden
programme.desc: As autumn falls, Christine prepares the garden for winter and bets Reg that her tomatoes ripen indoors.

programme.title: Gardeners' World
programme.desc: Monty and team share the best practical gardening advice, meet passionate plants-people up and down the country, and provide inspiration with visits to some of the UK's most remarkable gardens.

programme.title: Countryfile
programme.desc: Matt Baker and Charlotte Smith head to the High Weald, an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty on the borders of Sussex and Kent, to discover the role of wood, iron and clay both historically and for the future. While Matt meets a visionary architect, Charlotte explores an ancient clay technique for fermenting wine and catches up with a father-and-daughter duo keeping alive the craft of blacksmithing.

programme.title: Marcus Wareing's Tales from a Kitchen Garden
programme.desc: Setting out to bring in new livestock, expand the range of produce in his kitchen garden and get some insider tips on veg growing, Marcus heads to one of his old stomping grounds, Gravetye Manor. He explores their grand kitchen garden, before returning to his smallholding to help local farmer Stuart with the hay bailing. As he takes on the day-to-day challenges of farming life, gardener Anatoli shows him how to plait his garlic, before Marcus heads to a local artisan to get some of it smoked.

programme.title: Queen of Katwe
programme.desc: Kampala, Uganda. Young Phiona finds surprising distraction from her life grafting in the Katwe slum when she is introduced to chess by youth worker Robert, and proves to be talented at it.

programme.title: Tottenham Hotspur vs. Manchester City
programme.desc: Live: FA WSL Women's Football

programme.title: Great British Menu
programme.desc: The two highest-scoring chefs from Yorkshire and north east England must go head-to-head and cook their six-course menus again, taking on board their veteran's advice as they serve to the new panel of judges.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: Thomas Plant and Adam Partridge find some fascinating antiques and collectibles at Chiddingstone Castle in Kent. Paul also visits Chartwell House, home of Sir Winston Churchill, to uncover the real man behind the politician.

programme.title: Your Garden Made Perfect
programme.desc: Lisa and Justin live in a new-build house in Wokingham. Lisa is originally from South Africa, and the couple raised their two children there, returning to the UK a few years ago. They love their home, but the footprint downstairs isn't huge, and they are desperate to make more of the generous plot outside. Given their roots in South Africa, the family also want to connect more with nature. They go for walks in the nearby woods, but they would love their garden to offer them a `wild' experience.

programme.title: Inside the Factory
programme.desc: Gregg Wallace receives a load of tea leaves from Kenya and follows their journey through the factory that produces one quarter of all the tea drunk in Britain. Gregg turns his 20 tonne batch into 6.9 million bags.

programme.title: Six Nations Rugby
programme.desc: Ugo Monye introduces highlights from the penultimate and pivotal round of fixtures from the Six Nations, including England's blockbuster clash with Ireland at Twickenham. Eddie Jones's England side will be desperate to make amends for their disappointing showing against the Irish in Dublin last year, in which they were on the wrong end of a heavy 32-18 defeat. It was only the second time Ireland had scored 30 or more points against the Red Rose.

programme.title: Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy
programme.desc: Stanley Tucci explores Bologna, seen by many as the food capital of Italy. The region of Emilia-Romagna is home to a handful of globally renowned protected food products.

programme.title: Remarkable Places to Eat
programme.desc: Fred Sirieix is heading to Venice in the company of chef-restaurateur Angela Harnett whose Italian family heritage has given her a lifelong love of Italian food. Her Michelin-starred restaurant Murano, is named after one of the islands in the Venetian lagoon.

programme.title: The Misadventures of Romesh Ranganathan
programme.desc: Romesh visits Sierra Leone, a country with a dark past but great hopes for the future. With musician Gwyn Jay Allen as a guide, he explores its national parks and meets locals living truly off-grid.

programme.title: Doineann
programme.desc: When TomÃ¡s returns to his remote island holiday home he discovers his reclusive wife and child have vanished. With nowhere to turn and a storm approaching, he is forced to place his trust in the small community's lone retired police officer.

programme.title: Ali
programme.desc: The ten-year heyday of boxing great Muhammad Ali, in which he set about winning back his heavyweight title after it was stripped from him due to his stance on Vietnam. During this period, he converted to Islam, met luminaries Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr, and fought a legendary unification bout against George Foreman in a bid to reclaim the title he believed to be rightfully his.

programme.title: Natural World
programme.desc: Welcome to the Penguin Post Office, a little bit of Britain in the heart of Antarctica. Inside, the post office has everything you'd expect. Outside, things are a little bit different. Neighbouring the post office are 3,000 gentoo penguins. They are there to raise a family but their lives are far from picture postcard as adultery and robbery are rife.

programme.title: Question Time
programme.desc: Fiona Bruce presents a special edition on Ukraine, from London. On the panel: Nadhim Zahawi MP, secretary of state for education, Conservative, David Lammy MP, shadow foreign secretary, Labour, Vadym Prystaiko, ambassador of Ukraine to the United Kingdom and former minister for foreign affairs of Ukraine, Helle Thorning-Schmidt, former prime minister of Denmark, co-chair of the Facebook Oversight Board, and Sir Lawrence Freedman, Emeritus Professor of war studies at King's College London.

programme.title: Holby City
programme.desc: It's the moment of truth: whether Holby will finally get itself out of special measures. Meanwhile, Regina puts more pressure on Madge to betray Jac and the hospital.

programme.title: This Is BBC TWO
programme.desc: A preview of upcoming programmes from BBC Two.

programme.title: Marcus Wareing's Tales from a Kitchen Garden
programme.desc: Marcus develops plans to add a regional Sussex staple: nut trees. Jumping over the border to Kent he discovers the cobnut, a kind of cultivated hazelnut, and gets tips and tricks on growing his own.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Natasha Raskin Sharp and experts Richard Madley and Roo Irvine join the teams as they look around Harrogate for the best items to sell at auction. Natasha has a brush with the law, as she learns about the first police officers in Ripon and the criminals they would have had to face.

programme.title: Great Coastal Railway Journeys
programme.desc: Michael starts a new railway journey in Newcastle, heading north to Berwick-upon-Tweed. His route takes in the River Tyne, Hadrian's Wall, a former mining village and the fishing port of Amble.

programme.title: Inside Culture with Mary Beard
programme.desc: Whether it's in fashion and music or on our TV and cinema screens, the 90s are well and truly back. Shahidha Bari takes a look at the reasons why. She meets up with Ian Broudie of The Lightning Seeds and his son Riley, who has joined his dad in the band. They discuss 90s nostalgia, playing old and new hits to a Gen Z audience and the continuing popularity of their Euro 96 anthem Three Lions.

programme.title: BBC News

programme.title: Politics Live
programme.desc: The big political issues of the day.

programme.title: Ready Steady Cook
programme.desc: Mum-and-son duo Pat and Tommy are cooking up a storm in the kitchen today. Pat believes she has more traditional tastes, whilst Tommy's bag is influenced by his travels around the world and is full of more unusual ingredients. Inventive chef Ellis Barrie transforms Pat's ingredients into a beautiful selection of dishes which include scones with mango jam. Meanwhile, Tommy's exotic ingredients are elevated by our queen of spice, Romy Gill.

programme.title: Eggheads
programme.desc: The Eggheads team are made up of some of Britain's top quizzers. They face a team of challengers trying to beat the incumbents in order to win a cash prize. If the Eggheads beat the challengers, the cash prize is rolled over to subsequent episodes.

programme.title: Put Your Money Where Your Mouth Is
programme.desc: Seasoned pro Eric Knowles takes on Ochuko Ojiri at an antiques fair in Somerset. It's a battle of the antiques versus the vintage as the dealers employ two very different approaches to spending their Â£750 budgets, but who will prevail?

programme.title: The Heights
programme.desc: Ryan and Ana finally get together, but they are soon confronted by an unexpected third wheel. Pav and Claudia struggle to keep their relationship a secret and Mark finally confesses to his gambling addiction.

programme.title: Murder, Mystery and My Family
programme.desc: Top criminal barristers Jeremy Dein and Sasha Wass investigate a rural case of murder and moonlighting in Ireland in 1894. John Twiss from County Kerry was convicted and hanged in February 1895, protesting his innocence.

programme.title: The Real Marigold Hotel
programme.desc: Britt Ekland, Duncan Bannatyne, Dame Zandra Rhodes, Paul Elliott, Henry Blofeld, John Altman, Susie Blake and Barbara Dickson arrive in India and get their first taste of the chaotic traffic on the bus to Puducherry and their new home by the sea. Although Britt struggles with the heat and Paul is struck down with an upset stomach, the group throw themselves into their new surroundings ready to embrace retired life in India.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: The experts are hunting out antiques and collectibles at Greenwich Royal Naval College, Althorp House, Herstmonceux Castle and Reading Town Hall. Paul Martin visits Killerton in Devon and uncovers the fascinating story of Richard Acland, who gave away his fortune for his political beliefs.

programme.title: Richard Osman's House of Games
programme.desc: Every day this week, celebrity contestants Jen Brister, Kelvin Fletcher, Ian Moore and Dr Zoe Williams take on a series of quiz rounds selected by the host, quiz legend Richard Osman.

programme.title: Lightning
programme.desc: Comedian Zoe Lyons presents the fast quiz with a Â£3,000 jackpot. Six plucky contestants compete across six rounds, testing their general knowledge, quick thinking and speedy reactions whilst the ruthless spotlight patrols the studio. The contestants' motivation in each round is simple: stay out of the light and you'll be all right!

programme.title: Grand Tours of Scotland's Lochs
programme.desc: Paul travels from mysterious Loch Ussie, discovers wickedness in Strathpeffer and a fairy bridge over the Dornoch Firth.

programme.title: Nigella: Cook, Eat, Repeat
programme.desc: Nigella's grandmother's recipe for creme caramel provides the inspiration for a simple but elegant dessert of caramel custard. Nigella then rifles through her pasta collection to find the ideal pasta shape to go with her spicy sauce made from Italian 'nduja and cavolo nero. This is followed by a visit to the famous gadget cupboard for an electric potato masher to prep her brown butter colcannon, the perfect match to a dish of black pudding meatballs in tomato sauce.

programme.title: Mastermind
programme.desc: The specialist subjects are the `X-Files', the history of York Minster, England at the Cricket World Cup and the Brooklyn Bridge.

programme.title: University Challenge
programme.desc: The quarter-finals continue, with two more teams doing battle to reach the next stage in the competition. Jeremy Paxman asks the questions.

programme.title: The Real Peaky Blinders
programme.desc: As the Peaky Blinders start to evolve from a mass gang movement interested in territory and fighting into the first organised crime gangs in Britain, we follow the career of Birmingham petty thief Billy Kimber, who, with his Birmingham gang, rose to dominate the illegal money-spinning rackets around horse racing at the start of the 20th century. World War I disrupts his quest to build an empire, but after the war Kimber moves south to take over the rackets in the southern English racecourses.

programme.title: BuachaillÃ­ Ã³n Ãirne
programme.desc: Antaine Ã Donnaile and Cormac Ã hÃdhmaill undertake a kayaking adventure on the River Erne. The start of their journey brings unexpected obstacles and fast-flowing currents, but also the opportunity to visit ancient monuments. They spend the night at the ruins of Trinity Island's monastery, and find out how history and religion go hand-in-hand on many of the area's islands. Their final challenge is to master something neither of them has attempted before: paddle boarding.

programme.title: Newsnight
programme.desc: The day's important national and international news stories. With Kirsty Wark.

programme.title: BBC Weather
programme.desc: The latest weather forecast.

programme.title: NIFL Premiership Football
programme.desc: Nicola McCarthy presents highlights from the latest round of league matches in the Irish Premiership.

programme.title: Couples Therapy
programme.desc: Dr. Orna Guralnik guides a new group of couples. Michal is furious at her husband for not delivering the life she wants, Tashira resents Dru for insisting they live together, and Gianni and Matthew reel from Matthew's battle with alcoholism.

programme.title: Natural World
programme.desc: The story of a giant otter cub, who was rescued and is being raised by Brazilian naturalist Carolina Vargas. Sancho has to be bottle-fed, shown how to catch fish, and taught to outsmart the many predators of the Pantanal, the world's biggest wetland.

programme.title: What We Do in the Shadows
programme.desc: An old flame returns, causing friction in the vampire household, and an ancient vehicle is resurrected.

programme.title: What We Do in the Shadows
programme.desc: The vampires embark on a road trip from which they may never return.

programme.title: Suzie Lee: Home Cook Hero
programme.desc: Suzie Lee, winner of the BBC's Best Home Cook competition, shows how to prepare and present the perennial favourite, sweet and sour chicken.

programme.title: Countryfile
programme.desc: Matt Baker and Charlotte Smith head to the High Weald, an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty on the borders of Sussex and Kent, to discover the role of wood, iron and clay both historically and for the future. While Matt meets a visionary architect, Charlotte explores an ancient clay technique for fermenting wine and catches up with a father-and-daughter duo keeping alive the craft of blacksmithing.

programme.title: Fraud Squad
programme.desc: Today, Â£50,000 of public money and charitable donations disappear from a charity set up to help sick children in need of life-changing operations. A callous conman impersonates an NHS worker to fleece an elderly victim over a fake Covid-19 vaccination, and we join the fight against illegal fly-tippers who are costing local councils millions of pounds each year.

programme.title: Fraud Squad
programme.desc: A fraudster hands out public sector contracts worth over Â£1 million in return for kickbacks from his cronies, a mum is caught out fraudulently claiming disability benefits for herself and her two sons when they are caught bragging about their gym routine online, and one of the UK's highest-paid nurses is discovered working a second job while signed off and taking thousands in sick pay from the NHS.

programme.desc: Charlie Ross heads to Southwell in Nottinghamshire with experts Steph Connell and Mark Stacey and the teams, learning the surprising history behind the humble bar of soap along the way.

programme.title: The Repair Shop
programme.desc: First into the barn is Sandie Ennis, with a handbag that belonged to her late mother, the perfect project for leather expert Suzie Fletcher. Gordon Barnes has come to the workshop with a custom-made wooden windmill in the shape of Noah's Ark.

programme.title: Antiques Roadshow
programme.desc: The team are at Woodhorn Museum in Northumberland, a former colliery, where treasures include a gold Rolex from the 1980s and FA Cup medals won by a Newcastle United legend.
